pr_title: [JENKINS-61841] Limit the number of exceptions stored by CompositeIOException

timeline.message: [JENKINS-61841] Limit the number of exceptions stored by CompositeIOException

timeline.bodyText: Not strictly necessary, but seemed better to be safe than sorry in case someone makes a change that affects the auto-computed serialVersionUID in the future.
timeline.author: dwnusbaum

timeline.bodyText: Not sure about naming, maybe EXCEPTIONS_LIMIT or MAX_REPORTED_EXCEPTIONS would be better. Same with the limit, maybe 15 or 20 would be a better default?
timeline.author: dwnusbaum

replies.bodyText: Unclear why this is public. And if it's final, Groovy cannot change it.
replies.author: daniel-beck

replies.bodyText: I think its because its used in tests
replies.author: res0nance

replies.bodyText: Yes, it is public because it is used in tests. The class itself is annotated with @Restricted(NoExternalUse.class). I made it final because it does not seem to me like something that would be useful for users to change, but like I mentioned in the PR description, if anyone thinks it is important to make it configurable I can make it non-final and allow it to be initialized via system property.
replies.author: dwnusbaum

timeline.bodyText: I think that it is important to show users that there were more errors that are not being reported, but IDK if this is the best way to do it. We could also append a message to the message of the CompositeIOException itself.
timeline.author: dwnusbaum

replies.bodyText: better to add to the message imo, seems weird to have another object for this
replies.author: timja

replies.bodyText:
Yeah, my thought was just that it seems kind of random to have the outer error message include the number of exceptions that were removed, and this way you only see that there are unreported errors in contexts were you are looking at a full stack trace, which seems like the only time you would care, but maybe that doesn't really matter.
Any thoughts on the phrasing of the message? Maybe something like "... ($EXCEPTION_LIMIT of $TOTAL suppressed exceptions were recorded)"?
replies.author: dwnusbaum

replies.bodyText: Would that number be the total number of exceptions passed to CompositeIOException (of which EXCEPTION_LIMIT are recorded as suppressed exceptions), or the number that were removed?
replies.author: dwnusbaum

replies.bodyText: I would show the # of exceptions that the stacktrace has been discarded for total - exception limit if > 0
replies.author: timja

replies.bodyText:
How about using "discarded" to avoid ambiguity with what "suppressed" refers to?

Discarded (TOTAL - EXCEPTION_LIMIT) additional exceptions.
replies.author: dwnusbaum

replies.bodyText: I changed to modifying the outer exception's message in 341ffa9.
replies.author: dwnusbaum

timeline.bodyText: Not sure how to test this on other platforms without a ton of mocking, which I wanted to avoid.
timeline.author: dwnusbaum

timeline.bodyText: Now that org.junit.Assert.assertThat is deprecated, we have to import all of the methods individually so that we can import and use org.hamcrest.MatcherAssert.assertThat to avoid deprecation warnings without having to write that out fully-qualified every time.
timeline.author: dwnusbaum

replies.bodyText:
Wildcard import of org.hamcrest.MatcherAssert.* has been the preferred technique for me thus far.  That prepares for JUnit 5 (a long ways away for us because we need JenkinsRule).
Can you help me understand why the wildcard import of org.hamcrest.MatcherAssert.* won't work in this case?
replies.author: MarkEWaite

replies.bodyText:
It looks like MatcherAssert  only provides assertThat, but existing tests in this file are using assertTrue, assertFalse, etc. from org.junit.Assert, so we still need to pull in those methods somehow. org.junit.Assert also provides assertThat, but that method is deprecated, so we can't do a wildcard import of org.junit.Assert.* if we want to use assertThat from MatcherAssert without having to fully-qualify it at every call site.
We could convert all of the tests in this file to use assertThat so we could just import org.hamcrest.MatcherAssert.* and not anything in the org.junit.Assert package, but that seems like something best left for a different PR.
replies.author: dwnusbaum

replies.bodyText:
Very good point.  I've used the deprecation of org.junit.Assert assertions as a good excuse to replace assertTrue and assertFalse with assertThat.  The resulting failure messages tend to be better with assertThat than they were with assertFalse and assertTrue..
Agreed wholeheartedly that changing the assertions in tests is for a separate PR, unrelated to this PR.
replies.author: MarkEWaite

timeline.bodyText: Notably in this case, the suppressed exceptions in the outer CompositeIOException are actually instances of CompositeIOException themselves because of the fallback behavior in PathRemover.removeOrMakeRemovableThenRemove, each with two suppressed instances of FileSystemException. That means that the worst-case number of exceptions in a single CompositeIOException for the deletion operations in PathRemover with this patch is actually CompositeIOException.EXCEPTION_LIMIT * 3.
timeline.author: dwnusbaum

timeline.author: MRamonLeon

timeline.message: [JENKINS-61481] Note the number of discarded exceptions in the message of the CompositeIOException
